Instructions:

Welome to our HIT! We are cognitive scientists at the University of California San Diego, studying how people see complex shapes. In this study you will be shown a series of different shapes, and asked to color them in according to how you see the parts of the shape.

For example, look at this shape:

To many people, this shape looks like it could be made from two squares, like this:

In this study, we'll be asking you to color in shapes like this, with different colors for the different parts you identify. As the shapes you'll be working with are a bit more complex, there won't be a single correct way of coloring them in. However, you should try to color them in a way that is obvious to you- so that if you saw the shape again you would be likely to identify the same parts. If you are unsure, try to find a set of parts that looks right to you.

The specific colors you choose do not matter- in fact they are randomized whenever you start coloring in a new part of the shape. But there are a limited number of colors you can choose, so make sure you use different colors for different parts. Here, for example, you would be indicating that you think the two green squares are the same part:

To indicate that they are different parts, you would need to use different colors:

Each part can be as large as you like, but please don't use a single color for the whole shape- remember that you're trying to break the whole shape into smaller parts. This also means you need to color in the whole shape before moving on to the next one (like in these examples). If it's still a little confusing right now, don't worry- next we'll run through some examples with the interface you'll be using.
